awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: Digital Platforms and the Mediation of Technological Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a research project that studies emerging platform economics; three platforms are to be studied, those operated by Uber, Airbnb, and Amazon The project will contribute to theoretical understandings of emerging platform economies by bringing to light the ways that local environments mediate platform capitalism and to what effect. More broadly, it will contribute to NSF's research-focused Big Idea, "Work at the Human-Technology Frontier: Shaping the Future." Digital platforms provide the fundamental infrastructure for independent contractors working in the "gig economy" as well as for workers in the warehousing and shipping organizations that handle distribution for companies like Amazon. By generating findings about local mediation of platform capitalism, this study will produce recommendations for regional governments and firms looking to navigate these market shifts intelligently. The results of this project are to be disseminated via separate reports for regional governments, logistics and shipping organizations, independent contractors, and labor unions; accessible publications in popular outlets; an undergraduate course on platform economies; and the training and support of a doctoral student working in this area.

This project will analyze how local environments mediate platform capitalism through an empirical inquiry that focuses on the translation of digital platforms into urban regions in the US. Surveillance is key to these translations; all platform-mediated commercial interactions are designed to generate data that can be harnessed for building consumer profiles, mapping and predicting trends, and manipulating individual and group behavior. The platforms to be studied are those operated by Uber, Airbnb, and Amazon. Three primary research questions will guide this inquiry: (1) How are local organizational forms and functions altered in response to platform capitalism? (2) What resistances and affordances are presented by existing technological infrastructures? and (3) How does local cultural practice mediate the deployment and use of digital platforms? To address these questions, the researcher will use multiple qualitative methods including content analysis of industry, media, and government documents; 30 semi-structured interviews with key informants; and spatial mapping of platform densities and flows across selected urban regions. The exploration of the socio-spatial implications of large-scale digital platforms will draw upon, synthesize, and contribute to surveillance studies, science and technology studies, and human geography literatures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Large-scale digital platforms, such those run by short-term rental companies or ride-hailing companies, are reshaping people’s relationships to cities. These changes are neither inevitable nor uniform, however, as the unique history and character of cities modulates platform uptake. To better understand these dynamics, this research project explored empirically the mediating effects of existing organizational forms, material infrastructures, and cultural practices in selected US cities. Using qualitative methods, the research developed a "platform ethnography" that included content analysis of industry, media, and government documents; semi-structured interviews with expert key informants; and spatial mapping of platform densities across urban regions. By generating findings about the local mediation of digital platforms, this study was able to document specific challenges to city officials and produce recommendations for safeguarding the public good.

A total of 34 semi-structured phone interviews were conducted with representatives from a range of different organizational sectors, including industry, government, academia, labor unions, community groups, and non-governmental organizations. The average length for interviews was 70 minutes. Three large US cities were chosen as case studies for in-depth research: Boston, Austin, and San Francisco. Spatial maps were made to represent changes in short-term rental offerings over a five-year period in these case-study cities. By studying different city responses to a range of large-scale platform companies and types, the project was able to document patterns in platform deployment, along with cultural and regional differences in platform negotiation and integration. Findings are being disseminated through academic publications, media interviews, and conference presentations.

The intellectual merit of this project was its contribution to theoretical understandings of emerging platform economies. Specifically, it circumvented technological determinist arguments to outline ways that local environments mediate digital platforms and to what effect. The project drew upon and synthesized surveillance studies, STS, and human geography literatures to explore the socio-spatial implications of large-scale digital platforms. It makes a methodological contribution of advancing "platform ethnography" as a way to grasp platform dynamics in urban contexts.

There are several major findings to report. First, we found that short-term rental listings do not significantly overlap with the location of major hotels in our three case-study cities. This suggests that different neighborhoods are affected by those listings. A second finding is that resident displacement and gentrification are outcomes of short-term rental listings in many communities. A third finding is that cities mediate both short-term rental and transportation network platforms through forms of regulation, but such regulation is piecemeal and non-standardized across the cities in our study. Fourth, we found that ride-hailing platforms have catalyzed a downward spiral in many public transportation systems: as more people use ride-hailing instead of transit, transit systems receive less revenue and must reduce services to compensate, which makes transit seem even less desirable to would-be riders, leading more people to explore other transit options. Fifth, ride-hailing platforms maintain data monopolies and resist sharing data with city transportation departments, which obfuscates the detrimental impacts of ride-hailing services (e.g., increased congestion and pollution, dangers to cyclists and pedestrians) and interferes with city transportation planners' tasks of diagnosing city needs and providing services for the public good.

The broader impacts of this project contribute directly to the NSF research-focused Big Idea of "Work at the Human-Technology Frontier: Shaping the Future." Digital platforms provide the fundamental infrastructure for independent contractors working in the "gig economy" as well as for individuals renting properties through short-term rental platforms. Publications generated from this project highlight both risks to city systems and collaborative possibilities for cities to partner with platform companies to meet city needs. Mechanisms for achieving broader impacts include sharing findings with relevant stakeholders, publishing in academic journals, mentoring and training junior scholars, and giving lectures at universities and conferences.
